content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: Supine position, with the knee and lower third of the thigh exposed

A knee flexion of 20-30° (using a pillow under the popliteal fossa) allows for slight tension in the extensor mechanism, thus reducing problems related to anisotropy of the anterior tendons (caused by their concave profile when the knee is in full extension)[2][3]

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Locate and palpate the tibial tuberosity, patellar ligament, and the articular joint lines (medial and lateral) of the tibiofemoral joint

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: If possible (depending on equipment and subject's anatomy), visualization of the infrapatellar bursa
positionnement: In longitudinal view (parallel to the long axis of the thigh), place the probe 5 cm distal to the patella, approximately aligned with the midline

texte: The tibial tuberosity appears at the right portion of the image as a rounded area bordered by a hyperechoic line

The patellar ligament is clearly visible in the central portion of the image, crossing from left (narrower) to right (wider). Its fibrillar organization can be appreciated, where an alternation of fine hyper- and hypoechoic lines are present in the longitudinal axis of the ligament.
The infrapatellar bursa, often absent during ultrasonographic examination, is visible here just below the (distal) insertion of the patellar ligament. It appears as a small rounded hypoechoic area.

text: The tibial tuberosity is a bony prominence located on the anterior aspect of the proximal tibial metaphysis, approximately 5 cm below the apex (inferior pole) of the patella[2]. Its importance is largely due to being the insertion site of the patellar ligament (or tendon), and the pathology it is most commonly involved in, Osgood-Schlatter syndrome (see clinical relevance section below).
Additionally, we invite you to consult the pages on the quadriceps tendon and the quadriceps femoris.

content.subtitle: Osgood-Schlatter Disease
text: Osgood-Schlatter disease (OSD) is a traction apophysitis that affects the tibial tuberosity, following excessive and repeated traction from the patellar ligament. Apophysitis such as OSD affects children aged 10 to 15 years who participate in jumping sports. When repeated, traction trauma at the patellar ligament insertion generates damage within the apophyseal cartilage that varies greatly according to certain factors, including[2]:
Mechanical strength/resistance of tissues transmitting the traction force
The proposed pathophysiological mechanism is as follows[2]:
Chronic traction trauma at the level of apophyseal cartilage by the ligament/tendon
Micro-tears and widening of the growth plate
Avulsion of osteochondral fragments with tendinopathy within the ligament insertion (patellar in this case)

Ultrasonography imaging can be useful in visualizing many signs suggestive of OSD, such as the presence of calcified fragments, infrapatellar bursitis, and irregularities in the bony contours of the tibial tuberosity[2].

content.subtitle: Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Disease
text: Like Osgood-Schlatter disease, Sinding-Larsen-Johansson disease [SLJD] is a traction apophysitis that affects not the tibial tuberosity but rather the apex (inferior pole) of the patella. It is sometimes called 'pediatric jumper's knee' and also affects children aged 10 to 15 years[2].
